8.title: Alphabet’s Q4 2024 Performance and the Strategic Road Ahead: A Comprehensive Analysis
8.snippet: Over the past several years, Alphabet Inc. (NASDAQ:GOOG, NASDAQ:GOOGL) has maintained its position as one of the world's most influential and...
8.content:
1. Introduction

It operates a variety of consumer-facing and enterprise products, ranging from core search and online advertising to advanced artificial intelligence (AI) platforms and cloud services. These initiatives are underpinned by a robust ecosystem of tools—YouTube, Google Cloud, and Android among them—that collectively reinforce Alphabet’s formidable presence.

As the global economy continues to evolve, the technology sector faces both tailwinds and headwinds. On one side, AI advancements and digital transformation efforts create unprecedented opportunities for growth in areas like cloud computing, data analytics, and marketing solutions. On the other side, macroeconomic uncertainties, rising competition, and intensifying regulatory scrutiny present challenges that major tech companies must navigate with prudence.

Alphabet’s Q4 2024 earnings report offers an incisive look at how this leading firm is balancing its powerful revenue engines against emerging growth avenues. Advertising remains its core profit center, while cloud computing—particularly AI-driven applications—represents a strategic focal point for future expansion. Concurrently, management has signaled it will significantly escalate capital expenditures (CAPEX) in 2025, investing billions in servers, data centers, and custom-designed chips (TPUs) to secure long-term leadership in AI infrastructure.

Yet, these initiatives come with a suite of risks. The U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ) continues to probe Alphabet’s market practices, especially regarding its dominance in search. Additional concerns linger about near-term profitability, as aggressive spending can dampen margins and create potential volatility in free cash flow. The tension between capturing transformational opportunities in AI and cloud while maintaining comfortable profit margins exemplifies the broader story for tech giants in 2025.

In the sections that follow, this analysis delves into Alphabet’s Q4 2024 performance, evaluating how each core segment—search advertising, YouTube, cloud, and more—contributed to the company’s revenue and earnings trajectory. We further examine the rationale behind the rising CAPEX, contextualize Alphabet’s valuation against the broader market, and explore the major risks on the horizon. Finally, we propose a multi-year outlook, considering various scenarios that may lead to different valuation outcomes for Alphabet’s stock price. By the end of this discussion, it should be clear why Alphabet, despite near-term uncertainties, continues to be a central figure in the world of technology and remains a focal point for investors seeking exposure to growth in AI, data analytics, and digital advertising.

2. Key Financial Highlights for Q4 2024

Alphabet’s Q4 2024 results showcased both strengths and emerging challenges. Below are the headline numbers reported:

Revenue: Total quarterly revenue was $96.5 billion , marking a 12% year-over-year (YoY) increase. Although this slightly missed some analyst forecasts by a narrow margin, double-digit growth in a company of Alphabet’s scale remains remarkable.

The revenue trajectory for the full year 2024 closed at around 14% YoY growth, which has now decelerated to 12% for Q4—a likely indicator of natural slowing as the business matures, but still indicative of a robust core. Operating Income and Margins: Operating income reached $30.1 billion , a significant rise from approximately $26.1 billion a year ago.

Operating margin improved from 27% in the same quarter last year to 32% this quarter, highlighting the company’s focus on cost management and efficiency gains. Net Income and EPS: Net income for Q4 2024 stood at $26.5 billion , a 28% increase YoY.

Earnings per share (EPS) came in at $2.15, surpassing consensus estimates by $0.02. The figure was markedly higher than the $1.64 reported in Q4 2023. Market Reaction: Despite these seemingly strong numbers, Alphabet’s stock price dropped about 7% in the immediate aftermath of the earnings release and settled around a 9% decline a few days later.

Analysts attributed this sell-off primarily to concerns over the slower-than-anticipated cloud revenue growth (30% vs. the 32% that some had expected) and the announcement of $75 billion in planned CAPEX for 2025 (a 43% increase over 2024). Long-Term Growth Themes: For a company with a top-line run rate of over $350 billion, maintaining double-digit percentage increases is far from trivial. Many interpret Alphabet’s performance as evidence that it continues to capitalize on global digital transformation, harnessing the twin engines of advertising and cloud-based services.

In sum, Alphabet’s Q4 2024 results were impressive by conventional measures: strong revenue, robust profit growth, and improved margins. However, the firm’s shares were affected by heightened expectations in the cloud segment and the looming cost burdens associated with its rapidly rising CAPEX. The subsequent sections discuss these elements in detail to provide a more granular picture of Alphabet’s near-term and long-term strategy.

3. Advertising and YouTube: Sustaining Growth in Core Markets

3.1 Core Search Advertising

Alphabet’s long-standing revenue juggernaut is Google Search. In Q4 2024, search advertising revenue rose by about 12.5% YoY—an impressive figure in a relatively mature market. Retail advertising, specifically around the holiday season, drove much of that uptick. Both Black Friday and Cyber Monday in 2024 each delivered over $1 billion in ad revenue, highlighting consumer enthusiasm for e-commerce and digital holiday promotions.

Several factors underpin the durability of Alphabet’s advertising business:

Dominant Search Market Share : Google commands nearly 89% of the global search market, giving it pricing power and unrivaled reach for advertisers.

Advanced Ad Targeting Tools : Ongoing investments in machine learning help advertisers optimize campaigns, driving better results and ROI.

Integration with Google Ecosystem: Synergies with Gmail, Google Maps, Google Play, and Android mean that advertisers can target users across a wide range of use cases.

Despite these successes, there is a persistent question as to whether growth can remain robust over the long term. Macroeconomic headwinds and evolving consumer habits could, in theory, reduce ad spend, but the secular trend of digital marketing replacing traditional advertising suggests ongoing demand for Google Search placements. Moreover, as more users rely on the internet for everyday tasks, the volume of queries—and thus the potential for ad impressions—continues to increase.

3.2 YouTube Advertising

YouTube plays a pivotal role in Alphabet’s advertising ecosystem. In Q4 2024, YouTube’s ad revenue increased by 14% YoY. One noteworthy driver was political advertising tied to the U.S. election cycle, with combined expenditures by political parties almost double those of 2020. This influx of political ads benefited not only Alphabet’s top line for the quarter but also underscores the platform’s growing importance in reaching diverse, large-scale audiences.

Beyond political ad spend, YouTube’s sustained performance is rooted in:

Dominance in Video Content : The platform remains the most visited video site globally, hosting an expansive array of content from entertainment to tutorials and beyond.

Shorts and New Formats : YouTube’s expansion into short-form videos competes effectively with platforms like TikTok. This helps capture younger demographics and drives incremental ad placements.

Subscription Services: YouTube Premium and YouTube TV subscriptions, while not as large as ad revenues, represent additional monetization channels that can improve the overall revenue mix.

Critics sometimes question YouTube’s growth potential after major election cycles, given that political ad spend is cyclical and can distort quarterly numbers. Still, YouTube’s multi-faceted approach—combining short-form, long-form, live streaming, and subscription models—positions it favorably for steady expansion.

Overall, the continued momentum in Google Search and YouTube provides Alphabet with a stable financial foundation. These two segments regularly account for the majority of the company’s quarterly revenue, which in turn supports long-term investments in emerging verticals like AI, cloud computing, and custom hardware.

4. Cloud Business: Expansion, Competition, and AI Catalysts

4.1 Performance and Growth Dynamics

Google Cloud, encompassing Google Cloud Platform (GCP) and Workspace productivity tools, delivered $12 billion in revenue in Q4 2024—a 30% YoY increase. Although that figure stands as robust growth, it modestly trailed market expectations of about $12.2 billion. The shortfall was one of the reasons cited for the stock’s immediate dip post-earnings.

Considering Google Cloud’s relatively smaller scale compared to Alphabet’s dominant advertising operations, it is becoming an increasingly significant contributor to overall revenue. Management has repeatedly stated that the cloud business is critical for Alphabet’s long-term diversification and forms a crucial pillar for the company’s AI-driven future.

4.2 Capacity Constraints and the Case for CAPEX

One prominent explanation for the slightly lower-than-expected cloud revenue growth is capacity constraints. Alphabet signaled that certain regions faced limitations in data center infrastructure, delaying the onboarding of some clients’ workloads. Large enterprise deals, especially those requiring advanced AI compute capabilities, can strain existing infrastructure. This is precisely why management has committed to extensive capital expenditures in 2025—to expand capacity, build additional data centers, and deploy more servers capable of handling AI-specific tasks.

Despite these constraints, the outlook remains upbeat. Google Cloud reportedly secured multiple high-value deals in 2024, with several topping $1 billion in contract value. Moreover, the number of new, first-time commitments doubled YoY. Major customers like MercadoLibre and Mercedes-Benz are tapping into Google’s advanced analytics, AI frameworks, and global network to transform their operations.

4.3 Competitive Context: AWS vs. Azure vs. Google Cloud

While Google Cloud’s 30% growth is impressive, it must be understood within the landscape of the top three cloud providers:

Amazon Web Services (AWS) : Grew by about 19% in Q4 2024, holding roughly 31% market share.

Microsoft Azure : Posted a 31% YoY gain in Q4 2024, with around 20% market share.

Google Cloud: Up 30% YoY, at approximately 11% share.

Google Cloud remains the third-largest hyperscaler but has shown consistently high growth relative to AWS and is keeping pace with Azure. The secular tailwinds for all three providers—digital transformation, AI/ML adoption, data analytics—remain powerful. Even if Google never exceeds AWS or Azure in market share, it can still grow meaningfully as the overall cloud market expands, potentially reaching trillions of dollars in total addressable market size by the end of the decade.

4.4 AI-Driven Differentiators

A distinguishing element of Google Cloud’s strategy is its emphasis on AI tools and services. Products like Vertex AI, BigQuery, and the integration of Google’s AI research (think generative models, natural language processing, and custom silicon) give enterprises a strong incentive to choose GCP for next-generation workloads. The synergy between AI advancements and large-scale cloud infrastructure appears critical to Google’s plan for capturing new customers and deepening relationships with existing ones.

Enterprises often favor providers that can handle complex AI workloads in a cost-effective manner while offering user-friendly development tools. Google’s custom TPUs—discussed further below—are an essential piece of this differentiation. If these investments continue to produce strong results, GCP might not only retain but accelerate growth in strategic sectors like automotive, healthcare, and retail, where advanced AI workloads are becoming standard.

5. Capital Expenditures (CAPEX) in 2025: Balancing Growth and Profitability

5.1 The $75 Billion Commitment

Alphabet’s announcement of $75 billion in capital expenditures for 2025 has drawn widespread attention. In 2024, the company spent $52.5 billion, indicating that this new target is a 43% increase. This significant allocation underscores the company’s pursuit of a leadership position in AI, cloud, and data analytics, all of which demand state-of-the-art infrastructure.

The bulk of this spending is expected to finance:

Data Center Expansion : Building and upgrading facilities worldwide to meet rising demand for AI-centric computing tasks.

Server Procurement : Deploying next-generation servers to process training and inference for large-scale AI models.

Networking Equipment : Ensuring low-latency, high-bandwidth connections for global customers.

Custom Silicon: Ongoing development and deployment of Tensor Processing Units (TPUs), with each new generation aiming to deliver cost and performance benefits.

5.2 Justification for the High Outlay

Two primary factors underpin management’s decision to accelerate CAPEX:

Meeting Demand for AI: The computational intensity of AI workloads, especially large language models (LLMs) and generative applications, far exceeds that of standard business applications. Enterprises increasingly require advanced hardware that can deliver high performance without compromising cost-effectiveness. Infrastructure Constraints: Alphabet has hinted that certain deals in Q4 2024 were constrained or delayed due to limited capacity. By preemptively scaling infrastructure, Google aims to avoid bottlenecks and seize market share more rapidly.

Critics, however, voice concerns that near-term free cash flow and earnings could be pressured by such high spending. Large capital outlays translate into rising depreciation costs over several years, which may dampen net income if top-line growth doesn’t accelerate in tandem. Investors who prioritize short-term results might question whether these capital deployments will yield sufficient returns.

5.3 Benchmarking Against Peers

Other major technology companies are also boosting CAPEX, but Alphabet’s planned figure outstrips several peers:

Meta Platforms : Expected to spend $60-65 billion in 2025, directed largely at AI infrastructure and the metaverse.

Microsoft : Steadily increasing its CAPEX for Azure, though the company has not laid out an explicit figure as large as Alphabet’s $75 billion.



In a marketplace shaped by intensifying AI competition, many industry observers see Alphabet’s move as strategically necessary to preserve and enhance its leadership. The opportunity costs of under-investing in AI hardware could be severe, risking ceding ground to AWS, Azure, or other emerging players. Alphabet evidently believes that controlling the design and implementation of advanced servers and chips will be a lasting competitive advantage.

6. Regulatory and Antitrust Considerations

6.1 Background and Core Issues

Alphabet continues to face a high-profile antitrust lawsuit from the U.S. Department of Justice (DOJ). At the heart of the government’s allegations is Google’s near-monopoly in search—hovering around 89% global market share—and contractual arrangements that make Google the default search engine on various devices and browsers. These deals, the DOJ argues, restrict competition by limiting user choice and entrenching Google’s dominance.

Additionally, regulators have explored the idea of forcing Alphabet to divest certain assets, most notably the Chrome browser. Chrome does not directly generate advertising revenue in the same manner as search, but it acts as a gateway for billions of users, creating synergies with Google’s ecosystem (YouTube, Gmail, Google Maps, etc.).

6.2 Potential Consequences

If the DOJ—or other regulators globally—were to impose strict remedies, several scenarios are possible:

Divestiture of Chrome: This would break a key link between Google’s services. While some analysts estimate Chrome might be valued at $20 billion if spun off, the strategic impact to Alphabet’s integrated ecosystem could be disproportionately larger. Restrictions on Default Search Deals: Alphabet currently pays significant traffic acquisition costs (TAC) to manufacturers like Apple and Samsung, ensuring Google is the default search on their devices. Any forced changes to these deals could weaken Google’s funnel, although brand recognition might still allow Google to remain the top choice for most users. Fines and Monitoring: Regulators could impose financial penalties and require Alphabet to make changes to data sharing and interoperability practices.

6.3 Political Environment and Alphabet’s Strategic Posture

The political climate can shape the enforcement of antitrust measures. Some observers believe that potential shifts in U.S. presidential administrations or congressional leadership might soften the DOJ’s stance and result in a settlement. In any event, antitrust litigation typically extends over several years, creating a degree of uncertainty that might weigh on Alphabet’s stock valuation in the near term.

Despite this overhang, Google’s leadership has emphasized that any regulatory changes would likely not undermine the fundamental viability of its core businesses. The combination of strong user preference for Google’s search engine, a constantly evolving product suite, and the historically lenient remedies in large tech antitrust cases leads many to anticipate a resolution that would not radically diminish Alphabet’s strategic position.

7. AI Initiatives and Custom Silicon: Driving the Next Wave

7.1 AI-Powered Search and Product Enhancements

One prominent theme in 2024 was Alphabet’s active deployment of AI features across its product stack. By Q4, the company was rolling out Gemini 2.0—an advanced generative AI model integrated into search for more direct, contextual answers to user queries. This approach mirrors some of the capabilities introduced by competitors in conversational search, but Google’s scale and data breadth potentially give it an edge.

Early testers of AI-enabled search see summarized responses (or “AI snapshots”), adding a new layer of utility to simple queries. While it might impact the dynamics of search ads in the long run—particularly if more direct answers reduce the need for users to click through to websites—Alphabet’s overarching view is that improved user experience will translate to sustained loyalty and, ultimately, monetization opportunities.

7.2 Tensor Processing Units (TPUs) and Custom Silicon

Alphabet’s ongoing investment in custom silicon is another cornerstone of its AI strategy. Tensor Processing Units (TPUs) are specialized chips designed to accelerate machine learning workloads. The company claims that its latest generation, often referred to as “Trillium” or TPU v6, offers up to a fourfold performance boost compared to previous versions.

The advantage of designing custom AI hardware in-house is multifaceted:

Performance Optimization : TPUs can be tuned for specific frameworks such as TensorFlow, resulting in faster training times and lower energy usage compared to general-purpose GPUs.

Cost Advantages : By reducing dependence on third-party vendors like Nvidia or AMD, Alphabet can theoretically lower its infrastructure costs and pass savings to enterprise cloud customers.

Competitive Differentiation: Offering enterprises specialized hardware can be a selling point for GCP over competing providers that do not have proprietary AI chips.

Yet, custom hardware development does carry execution risks. Research and development expenditures are substantial, and any missteps in chip design can lead to delays and cost overruns. Success, however, would likely solidify Alphabet’s position as a leading AI platform, further justifying the large CAPEX for data center build-outs that house these TPUs.

7.3 AI Adoption in Enterprise Settings

Beyond consumer products, large organizations in finance, healthcare, retail, and manufacturing increasingly rely on AI to automate tasks and glean insights from massive data sets. Google Cloud’s ability to provide integrated AI solutions—ranging from advanced analytics and natural language processing to specialized hardware—positions it well to capture these enterprise workloads.

Case studies abound of organizations that leverage GCP to reduce operating costs, enhance customer experiences, or drive new product innovation. To the extent that Google can continue rapidly integrating generative AI capabilities, it might attract an even broader swath of enterprise clients, many of whom are still in the early innings of AI adoption.

8. Operating Performance and Profit Margins

8.1 Operating Margins

Alphabet’s operating margin increased to 32% in Q4 2024 from 27% a year earlier, illustrating meaningful year-over-year efficiency gains. This improvement demonstrates the company’s capacity to control operating costs while still investing in growth-oriented projects. Critics often point out that ballooning spending on AI infrastructure and data centers could erode future margins. However, the Q4 results suggest Alphabet has found ways to balance existing profitability drivers (like search ads) against heavier investments.

8.2 Cost Discipline vs. Growth Investments

Driving margins higher in the face of increased spending requires disciplined cost management, especially in headcount, marketing, and noncore initiatives. Alphabet is no stranger to resource misalignment—over the years, it has invested in experimental “moonshots” through its Other Bets segment. Yet, the search and advertising juggernaut typically finances these bets handily. The bigger question is whether the AI arms race will demand a sustained level of expenditure that outpaces revenue growth.

One key area to watch is depreciation, which will inevitably rise as Alphabet capitalizes a greater portion of its CAPEX into data center equipment and custom chips. Over time, higher depreciation could narrow the gap between operating income and net income, although if top-line expansion matches or exceeds the rate of spending, margin compression may be modest.

8.3 Benchmarking Against Peers

Companies like Meta and Microsoft are also juggling growth investments with margin objectives. Meta has improved efficiency by reducing headcount and refocusing on its most profitable areas, while Microsoft has historically kept steady margins even as it scales Azure. Alphabet’s Q4 margin outperformance suggests that its core businesses are healthy enough to support significant expansions, which is a bullish sign for long-term profitability.

9. Valuation and Comparisons with Broader Market

9.1 P/E Ratios and Historical Averages

Alphabet’s blended price-to-earnings (P/E) ratio stands around 22.8x based on early 2025 metrics. This level is slightly below the company’s 15-year average of around 24.4x. Meanwhile, the S&P 500 trades closer to 25.16x, exceeding its long-term average of 19.85x. By this measure, Alphabet appears attractively priced relative to a broader market that some observers believe is overvalued.

However, some discount may be justified if investors are factoring in regulatory risk and the uncertainty around heavy CAPEX. In other words, part of the reason Alphabet trades below the index’s multiple could be skepticism regarding the return on upcoming AI investments and the potential repercussions of antitrust actions.

9.2 EPS Growth Projections

FactSet analysts project Alphabet’s EPS to evolve as follows:

2025 : $8.89 (around 11% growth)

2026 : $10.17 (14% growth)

2027: $11.66 (15% growth)

These are healthy mid-double-digit growth rates, particularly for a mega-cap company of Alphabet’s scale. If realized, such consistent EPS expansion could warrant a valuation multiple higher than 22.8x, especially once regulatory overhangs clear and investors gain more visibility into the payoffs of AI and cloud investments.

10. Competitive Landscape Among Major Tech Players

10.1 Amazon

Amazon’s primary synergy with Alphabet revolves around cloud and advertising. AWS remains the leading cloud provider, although its growth (19% in Q4 2024) is slower than that of Google Cloud. Moreover, Amazon’s ad business—anchored by its e-commerce marketplace—has grown rapidly but is still smaller than Google’s core search plus YouTube revenue streams. Nonetheless, Amazon’s vertical integration in retail and media means it has multiple ways to gather user data, which could eventually challenge Alphabet’s dominance in certain advertising niches.

10.2 Microsoft

Microsoft Azure’s 31% growth is marginally higher than Google Cloud’s 30%, indicating a tight race for second place in the public cloud market behind AWS. Microsoft’s recent investments in AI, particularly through its partnership with OpenAI, underscore its ambition to integrate cutting-edge language models across its productivity suite and cloud platform. While it lacks Google’s entrenched position in search, it does pose competition for enterprise AI workloads, as many large corporate clients already have close ties to Microsoft’s Office and Windows ecosystems.

10.3 Meta Platforms

Meta shares Alphabet’s heavy focus on digital advertising, though through different channels (Facebook, Instagram, WhatsApp). Meta’s guidance for CAPEX in 2025 ($60–65 billion) parallels Alphabet’s large outlays for AI, suggesting that both see computational innovation as central to future growth. Meta’s short-form video push through Reels competes more directly with YouTube’s new formats, but the overall ad market is large enough to accommodate both players. The real question is which platform best adapts to shifting user behavior and privacy regulations.

10.4 Apple

Apple’s relationship with Alphabet is multifaceted. On one hand, Google pays Apple an estimated $20+ billion annually for default placement as the search engine on iPhones. On the other hand, Apple’s rumored in-house search initiatives could potentially reduce its reliance on Google. Apple’s tight control of iOS devices might allow it to shape user behavior, a concern for Alphabet in the event that Apple chooses to divert traffic toward a competing search product or deepen relationships with Microsoft’s Bing. However, given the enormous sums involved, Apple has substantial incentive to maintain a lucrative partnership with Alphabet.

11. Risks and Potential Headwinds

11.1 Regulatory and Legal Outcomes

Alphabet’s legal battles are the most prominent risk. A forced divestiture of Chrome or severe restrictions on default search deals could, in a worst-case scenario, disrupt a major source of traffic and revenue. Even without a drastic remedy, ongoing legal fights incur expenses, management distraction, and investor uncertainty.

11.2 CAPEX and Margin Compression

Spending $75 billion in a single year on data centers, servers, and chips will substantially increase Alphabet’s depreciation expenses. If revenue growth disappoints, profit margins could decline, leading to underperformance in quarterly earnings. While many analysts view these investments as necessary, the sheer magnitude of the outlay leaves Alphabet susceptible to overshooting capacity or encountering supply chain problems.

11.3 Foreign Exchange (FX) Fluctuations

With more than half of Alphabet’s revenue deriving from outside the United States, currency swings can significantly impact reported revenues and earnings. A strengthening U.S. dollar would reduce the value of foreign sales when translated back to USD, potentially depressing top-line growth rates in future quarters.

11.4 Intense Competition in AI

The AI landscape is no longer the domain of a few tech giants; numerous startups and alternative players are developing specialized chips, large language models, and advanced analytics tools. If Alphabet’s AI initiatives fail to keep pace with competition—or if open-source solutions match Google’s offerings for free—the competitive edge Alphabet expects to monetize through GCP and specialized AI services could narrow.

11.5 Macroeconomic Factors

A global economic slowdown can influence advertising budgets, e-commerce activity, and enterprise spending on cloud services. While digital channels historically rebound more quickly than traditional channels post-recessions, any cyclical downturn could result in short-term hits to Alphabet’s revenue growth.

12. Long-Term Outlook and Price Targets

12.1 Consensus View

Many Wall Street analysts maintain a “Buy” or “Outperform” rating on Alphabet, with 12- to 18-month price targets ranging from $220 to $280. These targets reflect varying degrees of optimism regarding the company’s ability to:

Navigate antitrust risks without severe structural changes.

Achieve a healthy return on its large CAPEX allocations.

Monetize AI enhancements in search, YouTube, and cloud computing.

Sustain double-digit growth in its core ad business.

12.2 Bullish Scenario

In a bullish case, Alphabet could surge toward $300 or more by 2027 if several conditions align:

Minimal Regulatory Disruption: The DOJ settlement might only involve smaller fines and modest concessions, leaving Google’s main revenue engines intact. Successful AI Rollouts: Enhanced search and new enterprise AI tools could open significant revenue streams, particularly if GCP wins large-scale, recurring contracts from blue-chip customers. Market Re-Rating: With mid-teens EPS growth, the market might assign Alphabet a premium multiple of 24–26x earnings, in line with or above its historical average.

12.3 Base Case

Under a more moderate scenario, Alphabet’s share price might settle in a $220–$250 range, reflecting:

Steady but Slower Growth : Core search and YouTube maintain double-digit growth, while Cloud grows around 25–30%.

Manageable CAPEX Impact : High investments weigh on free cash flow, but rising AI-driven revenue offsets a portion of the added costs.

Regulatory Adjustments: An incremental settlement or compliance measures that do not radically alter the company’s search dominance.

12.4 Bearish Scenario

If regulatory action is stricter or if AI investments fail to meet expectations, Alphabet’s share price could linger below $200:

Severe Antitrust Ruling: Forced divestitures or prohibitions on default deals hamper user acquisition for search, reducing ad revenues materially. Over-Investment in CAPEX: Data center expansions and custom chips might not pay off quickly, compressing margins and earnings for an extended period. Competitive Erosion: Rivals like Microsoft and Amazon could seize more cloud market share, while smaller AI specialists offer cutting-edge solutions at lower cost.

In this scenario, investors might demand a lower multiple for Alphabet’s stock in view of the heightened risks and uncertain growth profile.

13. Conclusion

Alphabet’s Q4 2024 earnings performance underscores the company’s capacity to sustain robust revenue and profit growth even as it embarks on ambitious new initiatives. Core advertising segments—Google Search and YouTube—remain dominant and financially lucrative, supporting a multitude of innovative ventures. The cloud division, though slightly short of high-end expectations, continues to expand at a healthy clip and stands to benefit from surging enterprise demand for AI workloads.

Simultaneously, the company faces a pair of formidable challenges. First, it must navigate mounting regulatory scrutiny regarding its market practices in search. Second, it must execute efficiently on its plan to spend $75 billion in CAPEX throughout 2025, predominantly aimed at AI and cloud infrastructure. If Alphabet manages to address both challenges successfully, the reward could be substantial: continued market leadership in AI-powered services, a deeper enterprise footprint through Google Cloud, and a return to valuation multiples consistent with its historical norms.

For long-term investors, the critical question is whether Alphabet’s near-term headwinds—ranging from antitrust action to heightened capital spending—can be outweighed by its potential for sustained double-digit EPS growth. Many analysts remain optimistic, highlighting the firm’s consistent profitability, strong cash balance, and the secular growth of digital advertising and cloud-based AI. On the other hand, skeptics point to the risk of slower payback periods for heavy infrastructure investments, potential regulatory constraints, and intensifying competition in AI.

Despite these uncertainties, Alphabet’s foundational strengths remain difficult to replicate. Its unparalleled search platform, broad advertising ecosystem, innovative cloud AI solutions, and cutting-edge custom chips give it levers that few competitors can match. These strengths, combined with relatively attractive valuations compared to the broader S&P 500, provide a compelling thesis for investors who can tolerate the ups and downs associated with transformative initiatives and evolving legal landscapes.

In sum, Alphabet stands at a pivotal juncture. Q4 2024 illustrated both its enduring core and the scope of its long-term ambitions. If the firm deftly manages regulatory risks and extracts value from its massive AI investments, it may reaffirm its status as one of the world’s premier technology enterprises—positioned not just to compete, but to lead in the emerging era of AI-driven innovation

0.title: Nvidia Stock Investors Just Got Great News From Amazon and Google-Parent Alphabet
0.snippet: In January, Chinese start-up DeepSeek introduced an artificial intelligence (AI) chatbot that quickly became the most downloaded free mobile application in...
0.content:
In January, Chinese start-up DeepSeek introduced an artificial intelligence (AI) chatbot that quickly became the most downloaded free mobile application in the U.S. Importantly, the base large language model behind the DeepSeek application allegedly cost $6 million to train and reportedly outperforms top U.S. models on certain benchmarks.

That shook Wall Street because OpenAI spent over $100 million training its GPT-4 model and supposedly had access to more advanced chips than DeepSeek. Investors rushed to the conclusion that U.S. companies have been overspending on AI infrastructure, and Nvidia (NVDA -4.05%) shares fell 17% on the news, erasing $600 billion in market value. That is the largest single-day loss in U.S. history.

Nvidia shares are still down by about 9% since DeepSeek rattled the market, and the stock is currently 13% off its all-time high. But Nvidia shareholders just got some good news from Amazon (AMZN -2.83%) and Alphabet (GOOGL -2.65%). Read on to learn more.

Some Wall Street analysts are skeptical about the DeepSeek narrative

Many analysts have praised DeepSeek for its engineering breakthroughs. The company reduced expenses by cutting down on data processing with innovative training techniques. However, several analysts also question whether DeepSeek has been completely forthcoming about its infrastructure and the associated costs.

For instance, Dan Ives at Wedbush Securities wrote, "Saying DeepSeek was built for $6 million with no Nvidia next generation hardware is likely a fictional story." Likewise, research company SemiAnalysis reports that DeepSeek not only had next-generation Nvidia GPUs but also incurred about $1.6 billion in expenses while training its model.

Importantly, cost efficiencies could actually boost demand for Nvidia graphics processing units (GPUs) by enabling faster diffusion of artificial intelligence (AI) through the economy. Put differently, if novel training methods reduce model development costs, more software companies will build AI products, increasing the total demand for Nvidia GPUs.

Amazon and Google plan to invest even more aggressively in AI infrastructure

Last week, Amazon and Google parent Alphabet reported fourth-quarter financial results. Both companies said capital expenditures would increase substantially in 2025, as they are currently supply-constrained where AI infrastructure is concerned.

Amazon CEO Andy Jassy predicted costs associated with developing AI models will continue to fall. But he also said, "I think it will make it much easier for companies to be able to infuse all their applications with inference and with generative AI." And CFO Brian Olsavsky told analysts that capital spend may exceed $100 billion in 2025, up from $83 billion in 2024, due to demand for AI infrastructure.

Alphabet CEO Sundar Pichai provided similar insights. He said a greater percentage of capital expenses are shifting toward inference as training becomes less expensive, implying DeepSeek's breakthroughs would not slow AI spending. Indeed, CFO Ana Ashkenazi told analysts that capital expenditures would total $75 billion in 2025, up from $52 billion in 2024, due primarily to investments in data centers, servers, and networking.

The capital spending guidance from Amazon and Google parent Alphabet corroborates the narrative that demand for Nvidia GPUs could actually increase as training costs decline because companies will shift their resources toward inference. Andy Jassy compared the situation to how cloud computing sales have actually increased over time despite cloud services becoming less expensive.

"What happens is companies will spend a lot less per unit of infrastructure, and that is very, very useful for their businesses. But then they get excited about what else they could build that was always cost-prohibitive before, and they usually end up spending a lot more in total on technology once you make the per unit cost less. I think that is very much what's going to happen here in AI."

Wall Street still expects Nvidia's earnings to grow very quickly

Wall Street estimates Nvidia's adjusted earnings will grow at 52% annually through fiscal 2026, which ends in January 2026. That consensus makes the current valuation of 50 times adjusted earnings look cheap. Admittedly, analysts have set a very high bar, so the stock could fall sharply if Nvidia misses those expectations.

Here is the bottom line: Nvidia shareholders worried about the DeepSeek drama can take a deep breath. Many analysts think more efficient AI training techniques will lead to greater demand for Nvidia GPUs. And evidence from the largest hyperscale cloud companies supports that conclusion.

Alphabet Stock Performance

Shares of GOOG traded down $6.17 during trading hours on Friday, hitting $187.14. The stock had a trading volume of 29,497,768 shares, compared to its average volume of 17,640,524. The company has a debt-to-equity ratio of 0.03, a quick ratio of 1.95 and a current ratio of 1.84. The firm has a 50-day moving average price of $193.12 and a 200 day moving average price of $176.13. The firm has a market capitalization of $2.29 trillion, a price-to-earnings ratio of 23.25, a PEG ratio of 1.39 and a beta of 1.00.

Alphabet (NASDAQ:GOOG - Get Free Report) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Tuesday, February 4th. The information services provider reported $2.15 EPS for the quarter, topping the consensus estimate of $2.12 by $0.03. Alphabet had a net margin of 28.60% and a return on equity of 32.49%. Finally, Phillip Securities upgraded shares of Alphabet to a "strong-buy" rating in a report on Friday, November 1st. Six research analysts have rated the stock with a hold rating, twelve have issued a buy rating and three have assigned a strong buy rating to the stock. According to data from MarketBeat.com, the stock has a consensus rating of "Moderate Buy" and a consensus target price of $209.13.

Insider Transactions at Alphabet

Following the completion of the sale, the chief accounting officer now owns 17,848 shares of the company's stock, valued at approximately $3,606,723.84. Following the completion of the transaction, the chief executive officer now directly owns 2,061,806 shares in the company, valued at $364,259,266.02. The trade was a 1.08 % decrease in their position. The disclosure for this sale can be found here. Insiders sold 89,529 shares of company stock valued at $16,600,078 over the last 90 days. 12.99% of the stock is currently owned by corporate insiders.

Alphabet Profile

Alphabet Inc offers various products and platforms in the United States, Europe, the Middle East, Africa, the Asia-Pacific, Canada, and Latin America. It operates through Google Services, Google Cloud, and Other Bets segments. The Google Services segment provides products and services, including ads, Android, Chrome, devices, Gmail, Google Drive, Google Maps, Google Photos, Google Play, Search, and YouTube.

5.title: Alphabet Inc. (GOOGL) – AI Policy Shifts and Strategic Advancements in Tech Leadership
5.snippet: We recently published a list of 10 AI Stocks Dominating Wall Street. In this article, we are going to take a look at where Alphabet Inc.
5.content:
We recently published a list of 10 AI Stocks Dominating Wall Street. In this article, we are going to take a look at where Alphabet Inc. (NASDAQ:GOOG) stands against other AI stocks dominating Wall Street.

Representatives from around the world are going to be attending the Artificial Intelligence (AI) Summit at the Grand Palais on 10–11 February 2025. The summit will focus on harnessing the power of AI systems as well as the risks posed by them. From heads of state and government and leaders of international organizations to business leaders, as well as representatives from academia, civil society, and the arts, it would seem everyone related to the artificial intelligence world is to attend. However, that’s not quite true.

READ ALSO: Top 10 AI Stocks Trending On Wall Street and 12 High Flying AI Stocks This Week

Reuters has recently reported that the U.S. delegation to the AI Summit will not include technical staff from the country’s AI Safety Institute. Vice President JD Vance is leading the U.S. contingent to France, with attendees including members of the White House Office of Science and Technology Policy: Principal Deputy Director Lynne Parker and Senior Policy Advisor for Artificial Intelligence Sriram Krishnan. However, Homeland Security and Commerce Department officials are not going to be there, particularly the representatives of the U.S. AI Safety Institute trips have been canceled.

The AI Safety Institute, created under former President Joe Biden, was created to mitigate certain risks from AI, having signed agreements with U.S. startups OpenAI and Anthropic for safety testing. The absence of these representatives implies that the Commerce Department, in which the Safety Institute resides, is still in the transition phase after Trump’s inauguration.

Regarding the discussion on AI, Prof Gina Neff from the Minderoo Centre for Technology and Democracy said that there is currently “a vacuum for global leadership on AI”.

Another professor from Southampton University seems to agree:

“DeepSeek made everybody realize that China is a force to be reckoned with,” says the computer scientist. We don’t have to just go along with what the big companies on the West Coast are saying. We need global dialogue.” -Prof Dame Wendy Hall, Southampton University.

For this article, we selected AI stocks by going through news articles, stock analysis, and press releases. These stocks are also popular among hedge funds.

Why are we interested in the stocks that hedge funds pile into? The reason is simple: our research has shown that we can outperform the market by imitating the top stock picks of the best hedge funds. Our quarterly newsletter’s strategy selects 14 small-cap and large-cap stocks every quarter and has returned 275% since May 2014, beating its benchmark by 150 percentage points (see more details here).

Alphabet Inc. (NASDAQ:GOOGL)

Number of Hedge Fund Holders: 202

Alphabet Inc. (NASDAQ:GOOG) is an American multinational technology conglomerate holding company wholly owning the internet giant Google, amongst other businesses. On February 5, Bloomberg reported that Alphabet Inc.’s Google has removed a passage from its artificial intelligence principles that pledged to avoid using AI in potentially harmful applications, such as weapons. Previously, the company’s AI principles included a passage titled “AI applications we will not pursue,” such as “technologies that cause or are likely to cause overall harm,” including weapons, reported Bloomberg. However, the writing is no longer visible on the page.

A Google spokesperson shared a blog post published Tuesday:

“We believe democracies should lead in AI development, guided by core values like freedom, equality and respect for human rights. And we believe that companies, governments and organizations sharing these values should work together to create AI that protects people, promotes global growth and supports national security.” – James Manyika, a senior vice president at Google, and Demis Hassabis, who leads the AI lab Google DeepMind.

According to Margaret Mitchell, who co-led Google’s ethical AI team and is now chief ethics scientist for AI startup Hugging Face, removing the clause may have implications for the nature of work Google pursues.

Overall, GOOGL ranks 2nd on our list of AI stocks dominating Wall Street. While we acknowledge the potential of GOOGL as an investment, our conviction lies in the belief that some AI stocks hold greater promise for delivering higher returns and doing so within a shorter time frame. If you are looking for an AI stock that is more promising than GOOGL but that trades at less than 5 times its earnings, check out our report about the cheapest AI stock.

READ NEXT: 20 Best AI Stocks To Buy Now and Complete List of 59 AI Companies Under $2 Billion in Market Cap

Disclosure: None. This article is originally published at Insider Monkey.

7.title: Tesla Investor Ross Gerber Slams FSD On Cybertruck As 'Not Usable,' Says It's 'Not Even In The Same League As Waymo'
7.snippet: A prominent Tesla Inc. investor and CEO of Gerber Kawasaki Wealth and Investment Management, Ross Gerber, voiced strong criticism of Tesla's Full...
7.content:
A prominent Tesla Inc. TSLA investor and CEO of Gerber Kawasaki Wealth and Investment Management, Ross Gerber, voiced strong criticism of Tesla’s Full Self-Driving system, particularly its performance on the Cybertruck, amid the company’s push toward autonomous driving capabilities.

What Happened: Gerber reported multiple disengagements over 40 miles while testing FSD version 13.2.6 on the Cybertruck, describing the system as “not usable” and noting it “hugs the lane on the left too far over.”

He directly compared Tesla’s technology to Alphabet Inc.‘s GOOGL GOOG Waymo, stating that Tesla’s FSD is “not even in the same league as Waymo at this point.”

Gerber’s comments sparked debate within the Tesla community, with some users reporting contrasting experiences. One user cited 1,800 miles of driving with only one safety-critical disengagement.

I have the exact opposite experience, have driven 1800 miles and had 1 actual safety critical disengagement. But keep talking your own book to save face you missed the rally from $200-$485 — Mark Ferrara (@MarkFerrara12) February 9, 2025

See Also: Apple Watch Users Are Strapping Them To Their Ankles — Here’s Why Its Leaving Some People Bewildered

Why It Matters: The criticism comes at a crucial time for Tesla’s autonomous driving ambitions. CEO Elon Musk recently predicted that Tesla’s FSD would surpass human driving safety by the second quarter of 2025. However, Tesla researcher Troy Teslike has raised concerns about the company’s approach, suggesting Tesla is attempting to skip crucial development steps that competitors like Waymo spent years perfecting.

Goldman Sachs analyst Mark Delaney, while acknowledging “meaningful improvement” with FSD version 13, maintains a cautious stance with a Neutral rating and $345 price target on Tesla stock. Delaney projects limited initial revenue from robotaxi operations, forecasting approximately $115 million by 2027 based on a fleet of 1,500 vehicles.

Tesla’s autonomous driving initiatives face ongoing regulatory scrutiny, with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration recently opening investigations into 2.6 million Tesla vehicles equipped with FSD technology following safety concerns and reported incidents.

0.title: Alphabet Shares Tumble on Cloud Revenue Shortfall. Is This a Buying Opportunity for the Stock?
0.snippet: Alphabet (GOOGL -0.49%) (GOOG -0.54%) share prices tumbled as much as 8.4% following its Q4 earnings report as the market came away disappointed with the...
0.content:
Alphabet (GOOGL -2.65%) (GOOG -2.71%) share prices tumbled as much as 8.4% following its Q4 earnings report as the market came away disappointed with the tech giant's cloud computing revenue growth rate. Like a number of other large tech companies, Alphabet is also set to ramp up its artificial intelligence (AI) infrastructure spending this year. News of Alphabet's AI-related plans was also a drag on the share price.

Let's take a closer look at the internet search leader's Q4 results to see if this is a good time to buy the stock on the dip.

Google Cloud in focus

Alphabet's Google Cloud business was in focus in Q4, with the cloud computing unit growing its revenue by 30% to $12 billion. That was a deceleration in revenue growth from 35% in Q3, and the total fell short of the $12.2 billion analyst consensus estimate, as compiled by Street Account. Operating income for the unit, meanwhile, soared from $864 million to $2.09 billion, a 142% increase.

The company credited the growth to its AI infrastructure and generative AI solutions while noting that its Google Cloud Platform (GCP) grew faster than the overall cloud business. However, the business was capacity-constrained. As a result, it will direct approximately $75 billion to capital expenditures (capex) focused largely on technical infrastructure, including data centers and servers, to help meet increased AI demand. That's a big jump from the $52.5 billion in capex the company spent last year. However, the company said it is seeing a lot of capex efficiency and strong performance stemming from its own custom TPU (tensor processing unit) chips.

Meanwhile, the company expects the launch of its new Gemini 2.0 AI model to help drive growth as it moves closer to being a universal assistant. The model has more advanced multimodal and agentic capabilities and will also be used to power its AI Overviews within search. It said its consumer Gemini app is also gaining traction.

Turning to Alphabet's other businesses, Google Search remained strong, with revenue climbing nearly 13% to $54 billion. It said it is seeing new ways in which people search, with its Lens solution being used for more than 20 billion visual search queries each month. It said that this is expanding the way its advertisers can reach consumers. Overall, the company was seeing the most strength among financial services provider and retailer advertisers.

YouTube ad revenue, meanwhile, climbed 14% year over year to $10.5 billion. The platform's growth was fueled by users spending more time watching videos on its platform. It also said that Google AI-powered video campaigns are driving better returns for advertisers.

One area of weakness was Google's Network ad business, which saw revenue decline by 4% to $8 billion. Subscription and device revenue, meanwhile, rose 7% to $11.6 billion.

Looking at Alphabet's emerging businesses, its self-driving car unit Waymo is currently delivering 150,000 paid public rides each week. It will expand its service to the new markets of Austin and Atlanta this year, as well as its first international city in Tokyo, Japan. It also said it is working on the sixth generation of its self-driving vehicle that will significantly reduce hardware costs. Alphabet also touted the progress it has made in quantum computing with its new Willow chip.

Overall, Alphabet's total revenue climbed 12% year over year to $96.47 billion, while adjusted earnings per share (EPS) jumped 31% to $2.15. Analysts were expecting revenue of $96.56 billion and $2.13 in EPS, as compiled by LSEG. Alphabet reported $24.8 billion in free cash flow in the quarter and $72.8 billion for the year. It ended the year with $95.7 billion in cash and equivalents and $10.9 billion in debt.

Is it time to buy the dip?

Similar to rival Microsoft, investors did not like the deceleration in growth at its cloud computing unit. They also seemed a bit surprised at how much the company plans to spend on AI infrastructure capex this year. However, neither should really come as a surprise. Cloud computing growth continues to be hampered by capacity constraints industrywide, and companies will need to spend in order to add capacity.

If DeepSeek, which shook up the AI world with its claims that its model was trained for under $6 milllion can eventually prove that not as much AI infrastructure spending is needed, that would be a positive for cloud computing companies like Alphabet. However, the reliability of DeepSeek's claims is in question and until proven otherwise, cloud computing companies will need to keep spending to drive growth. Google Cloud should be in a pretty good position to leverage its spending, given that its custom TPUs should help on the cost front.

Despite the market's reaction, I think Alphabet's quarter overall was solid, with both Google Search and YouTube showing their market-leading strength. Meanwhile, Google Cloud continues to drive both revenue and profitability growth.

Looking at valuation, Alphabet currently trades at a forward price-to-earnings ratio (P/E) of about 20.8x 2025 analyst estimates, making it one of the cheapest megacap tech stocks tied to AI.

Overall, I think the dip in the stock is a short-term overreaction to what is a very good long-term story for Alphabet. As such, I'd be a buyer of the stock on the dip.

1.title: I'd Still Buy Alphabet Stock Despite the Stumble Over Q4 Cloud Growth. Here's Why.
1.snippet: There's no denying it: Alphabet's (NASDAQ: GOOG)(NASDAQ: GOOGL) cloud computing business simply came up short of expectations in the fourth quarter.
1.content:
There's no denying it: Alphabet's (NASDAQ: GOOG)(NASDAQ: GOOGL) cloud computing business simply came up short of expectations in the fourth quarter. Investors aren't exactly thrilled with the company's intended expenditures on artificial intelligence (AI), either.

Shareholders paid the price, in the form of a sizable sell-off following Tuesday's release of the company's fourth-quarter numbers.

Don't be too rattled by the bearish response, though. A couple of important details that support the overall bullish case for the stock were obscured by all the post-earnings noise.

By the numbers

For the three months ending in December, Alphabet turned $96.5 billion in revenue into a per-share profit of $2.15. Both were up from year-ago levels and more or less in line with expectations.

All eyes were on the company's cloud business, though, which failed to satisfy. Although cloud revenue of nearly $12 billion soared 30% year over year to generate operating income of just under $2.1 billion, analysts were looking for a top-line figure of just under $12.2 billion. The small shortfall underscored the fact that Alphabet's cloud computing growth is slowing.

Except that as the chart below shows, going all the way back to early 2020, Google Cloud's top and bottom lines are maintaining the same forward progress based on the bigger picture. From a technical and mathematical perspective, the fourth quarter's cloud revenue growth is slower than the third quarter's 36% increase, but the third quarter's accelerated growth was something of an outlier.

Data source: Alphabet Inc. Chart by author.

Companywide, earnings barely beat expectations of $2.13 per share, while revenue was a few million bucks shy of the $96.56 billion analysts were modeling. Neither reflects Alphabet's typical strong estimate-beating form.

Again, though, a closer look at the numbers will show that except for the Google Network, all of Alphabet's core profit centers experienced robust growth in sales and operating income. It was the "other bets" division that accounted for most of the overall disappointment. Its revenue slipped from $657 million in the final quarter of 2023 to $400 million 12 months later, while its loss worsened from $863 million to nearly $1.2 million. Were it not for that stumble, Alphabet would have handily topped its overall estimates.

The other bets segment is where you'll find its most experimental and costliest projects, like the robotaxi Waymo, the life sciences brand Verily, and its robotics software Intrinsic. These efforts carry high risks, high costs, and high payoffs, but they don't lend themselves to consistent or predictable results.

Story Continues

4.title: Alphabet Sued By Popular Shopping Platform For $568M 12/24/2024
4.snippet: Alphabet Sued By Popular Shopping Platform For $568M - 12/24/2024.
4.content:
by Laurie Sullivan @lauriesullivan, December 24, 2024

Ceneo -- a subsidiary of Polish ecommerce platform Allegro, reportedly one of the most popular online shopping destinations in the country -- has filed a lawsuit against Google's parent Alphabet, Google Ireland, and Google LLC, for $567 million based on unfair search practices.

The lawsuit, filed Monday, was made by Allegro in a statement. Ceneo alleges it suffered losses based on Google’s practice of favoring its price-comparison service in browser results over Ceneo’s own service.

Ceneo presented the suit days after Google filed proposed remedies to the antitrust lawsuit with the Department of Justice that explained alternative actions the DOJ could take and the reasoning behind them.

The explanations focused on the sale of Chrome and why it does not fit the company’s actions that the judge found to be illegal. The actions focused on exclusive contracts with browsers such as Apple, smartphone manufacturers and telecom carriers.

advertisement advertisement

The DOJ suggested to the judge that Google should sell Chrome to curb its control of the search marketplace and allow rivals like Bing and DuckDuckGo to have more opportunities. Google argues that the market has become crowded and there are plenty of opportunities for rivals to compete based on their performance.

A Google spokesperson, in an emailed statement to Reuters, said the company disagreed with the lawsuit and was considering its options.

"Our Shopping remedy has been working successfully for several years and we continue to invest in formats that support brands, retailers and comparison shopping sites of all sizes across Poland and Europe," the statement read.

This is not the only suit filed against Google in Europe during the past month. Japan’s antitrust watchdog also reportedly accused Google of violating antitrust laws over its Chrome browser and bundling deals with smartphone makers, reported Nikkei Asia.

The Japan Fair Trade Commission (JFTC) alleges that Google broke the country’s antitrust laws over its Chrome browser. Now it could issue a cease-and-desist order. The investigation has been ongoing since October 2024.

6.title: News Weekly: Alphabet's earnings soar, new Zenfone Ultra, and more
6.snippet: This week we got a glimpse of how Alphabet faired this recent quarter, Zenfone 12 Ultra launches, Nothing teased yet another part of its Phone 3a,...
6.content:
News Weekly (Image credit: Android Central) News Weekly is our column where we highlight and summarize some of the week's top stories so you can catch up on the latest tech news.

This is Android Central's News Weekly, your go-to source for a concise roundup of the week's most significant tech stories. This is where we delve into the top headlines that provide the latest developments and innovations contributing to the digital landscape.

This week we got a glimpse of how Alphabet faired this quarter, Zenfone 12 Ultra launches, Nothing teased yet another part of its Phone 3a, Huawei's trifold phone and Meta gets into AI wearables while its Vice President of VR steps down.

Alphabet's Q4 report

(Image credit: Android Central)

Read more here.

Alphabet announced its Q4 results this week, and it looks like it had a 12% revenue increase year-over-year to $96.47 billion in Q4 2024. This brought the company's total revenue for the year to $350 billion, a 14% increase year-over-year.

Google Service's revenues increased by 10% to $84.1 billion in the quarter, which the company attributed to the "strong momentum across Google Search & other and YouTube ads."

Looking ahead into the year, the company’s CEO, Sundar Pichai, said in the earnings statement that the quarter was strong "driven by our leadership in AI and the momentum across the business."

"We are building, testing, and launching products and models faster than ever, and making significant progress in computing and driving efficiency," Pichai said.

Be an expert in 5 minutes Get the latest news from Android Central, your trusted companion in the world of Android Contact me with news and offers from other Future brands Receive email from us on behalf of our trusted partners or sponsors

This year's statement was very AI-focused, underscoring the launch of DeepSeek, which has turned the tables for many such companies developing AI.

"The reason we are so excited about the AI opportunity is we know we can drive extraordinary use cases because the cost of actually using it is going to keep coming down, which will make more use cases feasible. And that's the opportunity space, you know, it's as big as it comes. And that's why you're seeing us invest to meet that moment," Pichai noted during the earnings call.

ASUS launches Zenfone 12 Ultra

(Image credit: Harish Jonnalagadda / Android Central)

Read more here.

ASUS launched its newest Zenfone 12 Ultra. That comes packed with "prioritized simplicity, elegance, and beauty," according to the company.

On the display front, it consists of a 6.78-inch FHD Plus screen with a 120Hz refresh rate, and users can bump this up to 144Hz while gaming for titles like Honkai: Star Rail or Zenless Zone Zero.

When it comes to the phone's cameras, it has a 50MP Sony Lytia 500 primary lens with 2x lossless zoom, a 13MP ultrawide lens, and a 32MP telephoto sensor with "built-in" OIS (optical image stabilization). On the front, it gets a selfie camera at 32MP with a 90-degree FOV (field of view).

At the core, the Zenfone 12 Ultra comes with Qualcomm's Snapdragon 8 Elite, just like the Samsung Galaxy S25 series. The device also comes packed with AI tools like AI Tracking for subject detection in videos, AI Portrait Video 2.0 during 4K recordings for "precision tracking," and AI Voice Clarity.

Zenfone 12 Ultra is available in three colors: Sage Green, Ebony Black, and Sakura White. This phone is only available in Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Europe at €1,099 (~$1,143).

First look at Nothing 3a's camera

(Image credit: Nothing)

Read more here.

Nothing seems to be playing its cards right leading up to its new flagship launch that is set for March 4. This week, Nothing posted an official teaser image of the side of the Phone 3a that was glowing white. The only tagline by the company reads, "Your second memory, one click away."

This left many speculating on X if Nothing has teased a physical camera button for the Phone 3a — much like what we get to see in the iPhone 16 series. This would let users place the phone in landscape or portrait mode and press the side-mounted button instead of tapping the display.

If this were true, Nothing's Phone 3a would likely be the first ever Android phone to feature a camera button that could potentially allow users to control and swap between camera modes by slowly swiping along the button or pressing to snap a photo.

Huawei leaps on the multi-fold game

(Image credit: Huawei)

Read more here.

Recently, Huawei posted an "innovative product launch" teaser on X, which left people to wonder if the company's first multi-fold phone is arriving in global markets outside of China. The Chinese OEM said, "Be part of the extraordinary as we unveil the ultimate." The final part, "the ultimate," seemingly refers to the Mate XT, also known as the Mate XT Ultimate Design.

Additionally, the post features a teaser image that looks like the Z-Shape. Aside from users speculating it could be the Mate XT in its X thread, the company has only responded with "Stay tuned!"

In September 2024, Huawei launched the world's first multi-fold phone, which, when fully unfolded, the device features a tablet-like 10.2-inch display. The interesting thing about this phone is that users can use it in different "modes" or "states." Using a singular screen will give you a phone-style 6.4-inch OLED display while unfolding an additional screen provides a 7.9-inch experience.

At its maximum, the Mate XT is said to utilize the company's "golden ratio" of 16:11 in 3K resolution.

Meta's chase for the Metaverse

(Image credit: Meta)

Read more here.

Meta's Andrew Bosworth says 2025 is the 'make-or-break' year for the Metaverse. In a leaked internal memo, Bosworth hinted at the Reality Labs’ work in mixed reality will either be game-changing or a potential "legendary misadventure."

Bosworth adds that Meta is sticking with the metaverse, including Horizon Worlds, through 2025, although the company will have to "need to drive sales, retention, and engagement across the board but especially in MR." Reality Labs, Meta's VR division, has taken several billions in funding, but it hasn't yet lived up to its word of making it big in the VR world. Reality Labs also added nearly $5 billion in losses last quarter,

In other news, Meta's VP of VR and mixed reality (MR) has quit the company. Mark Rabkin has had the title of VP of VR/MR since the Oculus Quest 2 launched in 2020.

In a letter shared on Facebook, Rabkin describes his time at Meta as a "foundational, formative experience." Rabkin said he's leaving due to family health struggles at home, noting that he'll be taking some time off work rather before moving to a different position inside the company.

Rabkin has worked on many major projects from the ground up, like the Meta Quest headsets, over the past six years, including the transition from Oculus to Meta branding, creating record revenues of over 1 billion dollars last quarter alone. And played a major role in the Meta Quest 3S launch. According to Rabkin, Ryan Cairns, who formerly led Portal and Meta for Work initiatives, will now be filling his shows. Cairns is expected to assume the full title of VP of VR/MR at the beginning of March and will report to Vishal Shah, who will remain VP of Metaverse.

More stories this week

Those are some of the biggest stories from this week. Meanwhile, here are some other stories that are worth catching up on:
